description: @jack just setting up my twttr
Users gain the ability to search and discover content in real-time
Lists added the ability to group users.
Now a native feature - previously retweets were created manually by copy pasting text.
Default prompt for new tweets changed from ``What are you doing?'' to ``What's Happening?''
First Geo-tagged Tweets
Tweet IDs are no longer sequential
All links now shortened with t.co making link shorteners largely redundant
Twitter buys TweetDeck. First version was released in 2008.
URLs first indexed for filtering
Introduction of Country Witheld Content (Country-specific Tweet or Account Blocks)
The first Transparency Report published details on government requests
Significant changes to the API included removing the ability to request all replies to a tweet and different rate limits.
User IDs became snowflake IDs like tweet IDs
Previously lists were limited to 500 users. Lists expanded to 5000 users.
Twitter introduced the ability to curate collections of tweets using TweetDeck. Initially called Custom Timelines.
Web Search on Twitter became capable of retrieving any historical tweet since 2006. API access is still restricted to a few days.
Enhanced URL expansion metadata (website titles and descriptions)
Profile Geo enrichment metadata and filtering
Significant changes to User Profiles
Other tweets can be embedded - introducing a new way to disseminate information.
Like Collections but emphasising media. News organisations were the first to access this feature.
Commercial Access to Historical Public Tweets
Twitter removed the ability to see how many times a URL has been shared.
Twitter Favourites changed to ``hearts'' or ``likes''.
Photos quoted tweets videos and mentions no longer count towards 140 character limit making longer tweets possible.
Languages except Japanese Chinese and Korean can tweet 280 characters.
Ability to post entire threads of tweets instead of manually self replying
